135.01 POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY.
   The Fire Department shall:
   (a)   Combat fires within the corporate limits;
   (b)   Prevent the occurrence of fires;
   (c)   Inspect and abate fire hazards; and
   (d)   Maintain proper records of fires and matters related thereto.
      (1961 Code Sec. 135.01)
135.02 UNDER SUPERVISION OF FIRE CHIEF.
   The Fire Department shall be under the supervision of the Fire Chief.
(1961 Code Sec. 135.02)
 
135.03 POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE CHIEF.
   The Fire Chief shall be the commanding officer of the Fire Department and
shall have control of the assignment of the members thereof, and the direction
of the fire protection and prevention work of the City. He shall have full and
complete authority to issue such general or special orders to the members of
the Department as he may deem proper, and it is the duty of all members of the
Fire Department to render him and his order implicit obedience. He shall have
authority to promulgate rules and regulations for the efficient administration
of the Fire Department, the enforcement of discipline, and the supervision and
maintenance of the work of the Fire Department; provided, however, that no rule
or regulation shall be effective until the same has been approved by the City
Manager. The Fire Chief shall be responsible for the control and regulation of
all equipment belonging to the Department. He shall have such additional powers
and perform such other duties as may be prescribed by law.
(Ord. 2851. Passed 8-15-61.)
135.04 CLOSING STREETS IN VICINITY OF FIRES.
   The Fire Chief and his assistants and the police patrolmen shall be
empowered to close up any streets in the vicinity of, and leading to, any place
of fire.
(1961 Code Sec. 135.04)
135.05 POLICE POWERS OF FIRE PERSONNEL
   The Chief of the Fire Department, each Assistant Chief, and members of the
Bureau of Fire Investigation are authorized and empowered to exercise the
powers of a police patrolman in going to, while at and returning from any fire
or alarm of fire that may occur, and within 500 feet of the respective houses
of the Fire Department within the City.
(Ord. 7372. Passed 9-15-81.)
135.06 DEMOLITION OF PROPERTY AT FIRES.
   The Fire Chief, or any subordinate in command at a fire, shall have
authority to order the removal of fences, lumber or other combustibles, and to
order the demolition of any house, building or other structure when, in his
opinion, such action is necessary to prevent the spread of the fire, or the
public safety requires it.
(1961 Code Sec. 135.06)
135.07 DUTY OF FIREMEN TO ANSWER EMERGENCIES.
   All members of the Fire Department shall immediately report for duty upon
receiving notice that their services are required, except when on sick leave or
vacation. The Chief of the Fire Department, or officer in charge thereof, shall
have sole authority to determine whether a conflagration exists, to determine
the extent of an emergency due to conflagration, and to call members of the
Department to duty. Any member of the Department who fails to respond to a call
for emergency service shall be subject to disciplinary action if he is unable
to show good and sufficient cause for his failure to appear.
(Ord. 2851. Passed 8-15-61.)
135.08 BUREAU OF FIRE INVESTIGATION.
   A Bureau of Fire Investigation in the Fire Department is hereby established,
which shall be operated under the supervision of the Chief of the Fire
Department or such person as may be designated as Acting Chief of the Fire
Department by the City Manager.
   There shall be a head of the Bureau of Fire Investigation, who shall be a
member of the Fire Department and he shall be known as the Chief Investigator.
The Chief Investigator shall be appointed by the Chief of the Department. Other
investigators of the Bureau of Fire Investigation who shall be members of the
Fire Department shall be appointed to this position by the Chief of the Fire
Department. The Chief of the Fire Department may detail other members of the
Fire Department to temporary duty as investigators whenever necessary.
   The Bureau of Fire Investigation shall investigate the cause, origin and
circumstances of every fire occurring within the City. Such investigation shall
begin immediately upon the occurrence of such fire. If the fire is believed to
be of suspicious origin or causes loss of life or personal injury, an
investigator shall be notified immediately. The investigator will notify the
Chief of the Fire Department as soon as possible of his findings based upon the
investigation of such fires. The investigator shall take charge immediately of
the physical evidence, notify the proper authorities designated by law to
pursue the investigation of such matters, and shall further cooperate with the
appropriate authorities in the collection of evidence and in the prosecution of
the case.
   In addition, a written report of every fire shall be submitted to the Bureau
of Fire Investigation within two days after the occurrence of same by the
officer of the Fire Department company in whose jurisdiction such a fire
occurs. Such report shall be in such form as shall be prescribed by the Chief
of the Fire Department and shall contain a statement of facts relating to the
cause, origin, circumstances of such fire, injuries to persons, extent of
damage and other such information as may be required on prescribed reports.
   The Bureau of Fire Investigation shall be responsible for processing all
incident reports in the Fire Department and forwarding them to the appropriate
agencies with the exception of emergency medical reports.
(Ord. 8945. Passed 8-27-86.)
135.09 AGE REQUIREMENTS FOR APPLICANTS.
   No application for original appointment to the Fire Department shall be
received if the individual applying is less than eighteen years of age or more
than thirty-five years of age at the date of application: provided, that in the
event any applicant formerly served upon the Fire Department for a period of
more than six months, and resigned from the Department at a time when there
were no charges of misconduct or other misfeasance pending against such
applicant, within a period of two years next preceding the date of the
application, and at the time of the application resides within the corporate
limits of the City, then such individual shall be eligible for appointment by
reinstatement in the discretion of the Fire Civil Service Commission, even
though such applicant shall be over the age of thirty-five years, and,
providing the applicant’s former term of service so justifies, may be appointed
by reinstatement to the Fire Department without a competitive examination, but
such applicant shall undergo a medical examination; and if such individual
shall be so appointed by reinstatement to the Fire Department, the applicant
shall be the lowest in rank in the Department next above the probationers of
the Department.
(Ord. 11244. Passed 5-6-97.)

playgrounds and other recreation centers not definitely assigned to any other
branch of the City government, and shall cooperate with the Ohio County Board
of Education, the Park Commission and Recreation Commission and such private
agencies as are operating in the same field.
(Ord. 5715. Passed 6-4-75.)
139.02 UNDER SUPERVISION OF DIRECTOR OF RECREATION.

Recreation.
(1961 Code Sec. 139.02)
139.03 RULES AND REGULATIONS.

hereby adopted and made a part of this article as fully as if set out at length

   (b)   Whoever violates any such rule or regulation shall be fined not more

ARTICLE 141
Public Works Department
141.01   Powers and duties generally.
141.02   Public Works Director; Appointment; Qualifications.
141.03   Water Pollution Control Division.
 
CROSS REFERENCE
Cost accounts - see ADM.
125.06
 
141.01 POWERS AND DUTIES GENERALLY.
   The Public Works Department shall:
   (a)   Plan and design public facilities and improvements and make the
necessary surveys in connection with the same;
   (b)   Construct or supervise the construction and the maintenance and repair
of all streets, alleys, curbing, sidewalks, structures and appurtenances,
except as otherwise specified by law; drains, ditches, culverts, canals,
streams, levees, and appurtenances thereof; and the water supply and street
lighting systems of the City and all appurtenances thereof;
   (c)   Maintain the electrical facilities of the City departments;
   (d)   Service, maintain, and repair the automotive equipment of the City
departments, except as the City Manager may provide otherwise;
   (e)   Operate the necessary plants, yards, repair shops, and other
facilities required to carry out these provisions;
   (f)   Establish and maintain proper maps, cost accounts and works and
properties in its charge;
   (g)   Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by law; and
   (h)   Supervise the Water, Sanitation and Water Pollution Control Divisions
of the City.
      (Ord. 11350. Passed 9-16-97.)
141.02 PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT; QUALIFICATIONS.
   (a)   The Public Works Department shall be under the supervision of a Public
Works Director who shall be appointed by the City Manager.
 
   (b)   The Public Works Director shall be a person of proven executive and
administrative ability.
(Ord. 7181. Passed 1-6-81.)
141.03 WATER POLLUTION CONTROL DIVISION.
   There is hereby established a division within the Public Works Department to
be known as the Water Pollution Control Division to be responsible for carrying
out all functions and duties of the sewerage facilities.
(Ord. 7634. Passed 7-6-82.)
 
 
ARTICLE 142
Economic and Community Development Department
142.01   Department established.
142.02   Director’s appointment.
142.03   Powers, duties and organization.
142.04   Transfer of certain powers.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Establishing new departments - see CHTR. Sec.
25
 
142.01 DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established in the City a department to be called the
Department of Economic and Community Development of which the Director shall
have charge.
(Ord. 11350. Passed 9-16-97.)
142.02 DIRECTOR’S APPOINTMENT.
   The Director of Economic and Community Development shall be appointed by the
City Manager and shall serve at the pleasure of the City Manager.
(Ord. 11350. Passed 9-16-97.)
142.03 POWERS, DUTIES AND ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   The Director shall have the authority and duty of directing the
Department and any division or part thereof, and may recommend to the City
Manager the appointment of such professional and administrative staff as deemed
necessary for the efficient operation of the Department.
   (b)   It is the purpose of the Department to coordinate all related
planning, zoning, economic development, regulatory, code enforcement,
inspection, housing, neighborhood development and other functions assigned to
the Department and authorized by Council along with all powers, privileges,
rights, duties, responsibilities and obligations relating to such functions and
to facilitiate the implementation of the plans approved by Council.
   (c)   The Department shall operate with the philosophy and intent expressed
in the Preamble of the ordinance enacting this Article
142 .
   (d)   The Department shall be organized into divisions as follows:
      (1)   Division of Economic Development.
It is the purpose of this division to plan and recommend to Council through the
City Manager activities which cultivate and support economic growth and
development in the City. The division shall carry out the legislative
directives of Council under the direction of the City Manager. The division
shall coordinate its activities with the Mayor and Council, the City Manager,
the Mayor’s Advisory Commission on Economic and Industrial Development, and, to
the extent possible, community business and economic development interests.
      (2)   Division of Building Code Services.
It is the purpose of this division to provide and coordinate all functions
pertaining to building and housing inspection, and code enforcement services as
provided by law, including
Part Seventeen  of this Code.
      (3)   Division of Neighborhood and Community Development.
It is the purpose of this division to provide and coordinate all related
planning, zoning and regulatory functions of the City that are authorized by
Council and to assist the City Manager in the implementation of plans approved
by Council. It is further the purpose of the division to coordinate
neighborhood and community development activities authorized by Council and to
supervise and administer federal, state and other grant programs which address
housing, neighborhood and community development. The division shall conduct
outreach programs with bona fide neighborhood organizations as a means of
extending the City’s encouragement and support of neighborhood-based
revitalization, preservation, and development activities. The division shall
administer the City’s housing programs and related activities as authorized by
Council.
(Ord. 11350. Passed 9-16-97.)
142.04 TRANSFER OF CERTAIN POWERS.
   There is hereby transferred to the Department of Economic and Community
Development all of the staff planning functions of the Urban Renewal Authority
and the Planning Commission including all the powers, privileges, rights,
duties, responsibilities and obligations related to these functions. It is the
intent of this provision to transfer to the Department of Economic and
Community Development all of the purposes, powers, rights, duties,
responsibilities and obligations of the former Department of Development and
the former Community Development Block Grant Department, including the
administration of all programs of the City funded pursuant to the Housing and
Community Development Act of 1974, 42 U.S.C. §5301 et seq., as amended, and all
regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, including, but not limited to, 24
C.F.R. Part 570, and any future amendments to such statutes and regulations.
(Ord. 11350. Passed 9-16-97.)

ARTICLE 148
Human Resources Department
148.01   Department established.

148.01 DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established in the City a department to be called the Human
Resources Department, of which the Director shall have charge.
(Ord. 11664. Passed 10-7-98.)
148.02 APPOINTMENT OF DIRECTOR.
   The City Manager shall appoint the Human Resources Director, who shall serve
at the will and pleasure of the City Manager.
(Ord. 11664. Passed 10-7-98.)
148.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Director shall have the authority and be required to:
      (1)   Supervise and direct the work of the employees of the Department.
      (2)   Promulgate and recommend rules, regulations and policies necessary
for the efficient administration of the City to the City Manager for approval
and adoption.
      (3)   Make investigation into the City’s compliance with federal, state
and local laws, and to take action to ascertain compliance.
      (4)   Attend the meetings of the Municipal, Police and Fire Civil Service
Commissions and administer the rules and regulations; arrange, provide and hold
competitive testing; recommend changes to the Rules and Regulations of the
Commissions, consistent with federal, state and local laws, regulations or
policies; prepare the annual report; and such other duties as assigned under
the direction of the Commissions.
      (5)   Make a study of the rates of compensation being paid for each class
of position and to prepare a report setting forth a schedule of compensations
for each of the positions with a minimum salary rate, a maximum salary rate and
such intermediate salary rates as may be necessary and equitable.
      (6)   Establish and maintain in suitable form a roster of the officers
and employees in the service of the City, the department with which each is
connected, the position held by each and the amount of compensation that each
receives.
      (7)   Serve as the chair of the Job Classification Committee, which is
hereby established to administer and amend the City’s classification plan.
      (8)   Administer the City’s drug and alcohol testing program as required
by federal and state legislation and City policy.
      (9)   Advise the City Manager on matters of personnel administration and
perform such other duties and responsibilities as assigned and directed by the
City Manager or required by law.
   (b)   It shall be the purpose of the Department to:
      (1)   Provide for the proper administration and to centrally handle the
human resources, labor relations and personnel functions of the City.
      (2)   Administer the employee benefits program as established and adopted
by Council.
      (3)   Maintain a confidential personnel file on each employee as required
by law.
         (Ord. 11664. Passed 10-7-98.)

149.01 DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT HEADS GENERALLY.
   Department heads shall, under direction of the City Manager, perform the
duties assigned by ordinances of the City now in effect, or which may hereafter
be adopted, and by rules of the City Manager.
(1961 Code Sec. 143.01)
149.02 OFFICIAL BONDS.
   (a)   All employees of the Director of Finance's office receiving or
handling money, all other persons authorized to collect or handle any money
belonging to the City, and all other persons required by law to be bonded,
shall be bonded with corporate surety bonds written by a surety company
authorized to operate in the State of West Virginia, in such amounts as Council
shall determine by ordinance.
   (b)   The premiums on surety bonds required of officers and employees shall
be paid by the City out of the appropriations for the departments concerned.
   (c)   All surety bonds required of officers and employees shall be approved
as to form by the City Solicitor and City Manager and filed with the City
Clerk, who shall keep a record thereof.
(1961 Code Sec. 143.02)
149.03 COMPENSATION OF OFFICERS OTHER THAN REGULAR SALARY.
   No officer or official of the City shall receive compensation from the City
or from any board or commission of the City, other than his regular salary.
This prohibition against payment of compensation shall apply not only to
regular boards and commissions of the City as provided for by the Charter, but
also to any boards or commissions of the City established under authority of
the acts of the legislature of the State, of the Congress of the United States
or of any other authority, and shall include special boards or commissions
which may hereafter be established by Council for the purpose of permitting
Municipal projects to be constructed on a self-liquidating basis, through the
issuance of revenue bonds or other forms of financing of a self-liquidating
nature.
(1961 Code Sec. 143.03)
149.04 EMPLOYEES' RETIREMENT AND BENEFIT FUND; DEFINED CONTRIBUTION PLAN.
   (a)   Employees’ Retirement and Benefit Fund.
      (1)   Council does hereby establish an Employees' Retirement and Benefit
Fund for the employees of the City as set forth and described in West Virginia
Code 8-22-2, by adopting all of the terms and provisions of West Virginia Code
Article 8-22.
      (2)   The City's Employees' Retirement and Benefit Fund is hereby amended
to allow a designated beneficiary to receive retirement pension upon the death
of a member receiving retirement pension pursuant to West Virginia Code 8-22-9
(b).
      (3)   Contributions made by a member of the Fund shall be before tax,
pursuant to Section 414 (h) (2) of the Internal Revenue Code [26 U.S.C. Sec.
414 (h) (2)].
      (4)   Members of the Fund who have been honorably discharged from the
military shall receive up to two years prior service credit for military
service prior to their employment with the City.
      (5)   "Average salary" means the highest annual salary earned by a member
during a period of three consecutive years within the total service of the
member pursuant to West Virginia Code 8-22-3 (k).
      (6)   Pursuant to West Virginia Code 8-22-5, employees who did not
participate in the Fund when first eligible or who were not permitted to join
the Fund when first eligible or who were not permitted to join the Fund when
they were first hired due to the prior age sixty limitation, may now
participate in the Fund. Such members may purchase prior service by paying into
the Fund the employee contributions they would have contributed had they been
in the Fund plus interest at the rate of six percent (6%) annually. Members
shall be given two years to pay these contributions.
(Ord. 11243. Passed 5-6-97.)
      (7)   There is hereby established an ad-hoc cost-of-living increase for
retired members and their beneficiaries which shall be based upon the increase
in the National Consumer Price Index, but in no case shall exceed three percent
(3%) per annum. Such increase must be deemed financially feasible based upon an
actuarial certification of the Municipal Employees’ Pension Fund. There may be
future ad-hoc cost-of-living increases, however, such is contingent upon a
yearly resolution which may be adopted by Council. The resolution must
stipulate that an ad-hoc cost-of-living increase is financially feasible based
upon an actuarial certification of the Municipal Employees’ Pension Fund. This
ad-hoc cost-of-living increase will be given in the form of one lump sum
payment per calendar year.
(Ord. 11989. Passed 2-15-00.)
   (b)   Defined Contribution Plan.
      (1)   Council does hereby establish a Defined Contribution Plan, which
shall consist of one or more plans approved by Council by ordinance
(collectively, the “Plan”).
      (2)   The Plan shall meet the requirements of Section 401(a) of the
Internal Revenue Code and shall be administered pursuant to the plan and trust
agreement to be incorporated by reference into the ordinance approving the
Plan.
      (3)   Each new employee of the City may, within thirty days of
commencement of employment, and each present employee of the City may:
         A.   On or before September 30, 1997,
         B.   Within thirty days after attaining ten years of total service
credit, or
         C.   Within thirty days after attaining thirty-five years of total
service credit,
make an irrevocable election to participate in the Plan and to waive any right
to participate, or in the case of a present employee to participate further, in
the Employees’ Retirement and Benefit Fund. In the case of a present employee
so electing, that employee’s total service credit shall be frozen as of the
election, and that employee shall be entitled only to those benefits under the
Employees’ Retirement and Benefit Fund that shall have accrued as of the
election, but shall accrue no further benefits under the Employees’ Retirement
and Benefit Fund.
      (4)   The City shall contribute to the Plan an amount equal to six
percent (6%) of earnings annually on behalf of each participating employee, and
each participating employee shall contribute not less than six percent (6%) of
earnings annually. Contributions made by the employee shall be before tax,
pursuant to Section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code (25 U.S.C. Sec. 414
(h)(2)).
      (5)   “Employee” for the purpose of this section shall be defined as in
Section
159.19(h) of this Code.
         (Ord. 11243. Passed 5-6-97.)
149.05 BOARD OF TRUSTEES.
   The Board of Trustees of the Employees' Retirement and Benefit Fund, under
the terms and provisions of West Virginia Code 8-22-4, shall consist of the
Mayor and four members of the Fund who shall hereafter be appointed by the
Mayor with the advice and consent of the majority of the members of the Fund.
The initial appointments of the four members of the Board of Trustees shall be
for terms of one, two, three and four years respectively, after which all
appointments shall be for the term of four years. The presiding officer of the
board shall be the Mayor, and the secretary thereof shall be appointed by the
Board of Trustees.
(1961 Code Sec. 143.05)
149.06 DISABILITY, ACCIDENT AND HEALTH INSURANCE.
   (a)   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed to enter into and
renew from time to time a contract with some insurance company that has paid to
the City all license insurance taxes due to the City, on behalf of the City, a
Municipal corporation, as "Employer" providing indemnity for total disability
caused by bodily injury effected through nonoccupational accidental means and
for total disability caused by disease for the benefit of all employees of the
City who elect to subscribe for such indemnity.
   (b)   The contract herein provided shall conform to and fulfill the
requirements of group insurance contracts as provided in West Virginia Code
Article 33-13 et seq. and shall not be binding upon the City or its employees
until it has been approved by the Insurance Commissioner of the State.
(1961 Code Sec. 143.06)
149.07 CHOICE OF EMPLOYEE; PAYROLL DEDUCTIONS.
   (a)   All employees of the City who elect to pay premiums for the insurance
described in Section
149.06, while employed by the City, shall be considered as eligible to receive
benefits under the contract.
 
   (b)   All employees who elect to subscribe for such insurance shall evidence
their election in writing to the City Manager, thereby authorizing and
directing the City Manager to deduct from the wages due and to become due to
the respective employees a sufficient amount to pay current premiums for such
insurance. The amount assessed for premiums under the insurance coverage shall
be paid entirely by the employees so insured.
(1961 Code Sec. 143.07)
149.08 CITY AS COLLECTING AGENT.
   The City, as employer, shall act as collecting agent for the premiums so
deducted from the wages of the insured employees and shall remit the amounts so
collected to the duly authorized representative of some insurance company, as
set forth in Section
149.06 with which the City has entered into a contract, in such amounts and at
such periods as provided for in the contract. The City shall not incur any
obligation to the insurance company other than the duty of collecting and
remitting the premiums deducted from the employees' wages, and shall make no
warrants or representations to the insurance company or incur any liability
whatsoever with reference to the insurance contract except as hereinbefore
provided.
(1961 Code Sec. 143.08)
149.09 ENTERING MILITARY SERVICE.
   Any official or employee of the City who enters, or has entered, any branch
of the military or naval service of the United States of America, whether such
entry is, or has been, by voluntary enlistment, or by induction under any
Federal Act in regards to selective training and service, shall notify his/her
immediate supervisor immediately and request military leave for any necessary
leaves of absence.
(Ord. 11993. Passed 3-7-00.)
149.10 RECORDS TO BE CITY PROPERTY.
   All correspondence, documents and records of any official or employee of the
City government shall be the property of the City government and upon the
retirement of any officer or employee from office such material shall be turned
over to his successor. No official or employee, upon leaving office, shall
withhold or retain in his possession any such material.
(1961 Code Sec. 143.10)
149.11 COMPULSORY RETIREMENT.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
149.11 was repealed by Ordinance 11994, passed March 7, 2000.)
149.12 VACATIONS.
   (a)   The heads of all departments, with the approval of the City Manager
shall grant annual vacations with pay to all full-time permanent employees in
the classified and unclassified services of the City. Each full pay period
worked by an employee, including vacation time and allowable sick leave, shall
entitle the employee to earned vacation credits on the following schedule:
 
8 Hour Shift Employees
0 - 60 months –    3.07 hours/pay period
(80 hours = 10 days = 2 weeks)
61 - 120 months –    4.61 hours/pay period
(120 hours = 15 days = 3 weeks)
121+ months –    6.15 hours/pay period
(160 hours = 20 days = 4 weeks)
10 Hour Shift Employees
0 - 60 months –    3.07 hours/pay period
(80 hours = 8 days = 2 weeks)
61 - 120 months --    4.61 hours/pay period
(120 hours = 12 days = 3 weeks)
121+ months --    6.15 hours/pay period
(160 hours = 16 days = 4 weeks)
12 Hour Shift Employees
0 - 60 months –    3.23 hours/pay period
(84 hours = 7 days = 2 weeks)
61 - 120 months –    4.61 hours/pay period
(120 hours = 10 days = 3 weeks)
121+ months –    6.46 hours/pay period
(168 hours = 14 days = 4 weeks)
24 Hour Shift Employees
0 - 60 months –    4.61 hours/pay period
(120 hours = 5 days = 2 weeks)
61 - 120 months –    6.46 hours/pay period
(168 hours = 7 days = 3 weeks)
121+ months –    9.23 hours/pay period
(240 hours = 10 days = 4 weeks)
   (b)   Annual vacations with pay may be scheduled for a period not to exceed
the earned vacation credits at the start of the vacation period. Vacations
shall be granted at such time as will least interfere with the efficient
operation of a department, and particular consideration shall be given to the
number of employees absent on vacation and sick leave at the same time. Any
vacation credits earned during the calendar year and not taken prior to
December 31st of the following year, must be scheduled and used prior to March
1st of the next succeeding calendar year.
(Ord. 11394. Passed 1-6-98.)
149.13 SICK LEAVE.
   Sick leave with pay shall accrue for all regular, full-time employees in the
classified and unclassified services of the City. Sick leave shall accrue at
the rate of one day per month. Employees on leave without pay, Workers’
Compensation and FMLA shall not accrue sick leave benefits. An employee shall
be permitted to accumulate sick leave credit during his/her first six months of
employment but shall not be permitted to use such sick leave credit during the
first six months of employment. An employee shall be eligible to use accrued
sick leave credit only after he/she has completed his/her first six months of
employment. Sick leave shall be entered on the employee’s service record.
   In order to receive compensation while absent on sick leave, each employee
must notify his/her immediate supervisor of his/her illness no later than one-
half hour before the time set for beginning his/her daily duties, or as may be
specified by the head of the department. Payments for sick leave shall not be
made for an unreported and unexcused absence. Unexcused absence shall be
considered sufficient cause for suspension of an employee by the head of the
department. Employees shall not take sick leave except in cases of absolute
necessity. The City Manager may order a physical examination of any employee on
sick leave or of any employee who has taken sick leave. Repeated sick leave
taken by an employee for minor or trivial illness may constitute cause for
disciplinary action, including but not limited to, removing such employee from
service.
(Ord. 11820. Passed 6-15-99.)
149.14 INJURY LEAVE.
   Employees injured or incapacitated in the actual discharge of duty, who are
compelled to be absent from duty, shall be eligible to receive Workers’
Compensation benefits as approved and required by West Virginia Workers’
Compensation. No employee shall be eligible to receive any leave benefits from
the City during any time period in which Workers’ Compensation benefits have
been filed. Employees shall not lose any seniority or service credits while off
work due to a compensable injury.
(Ord. 11995. Passed 3-7-00.)
149.15 SPECIAL ABSENCES.
   (a)   The City Manager is authorized and hereby directed to establish
administrative policies that govern the leave for the following:
      (1)   Funeral leave.
      (2)   Family and medical leave.
      (3)   Jury duty/court attendance.
      (4)   Medical leave.
   (b)   Time off during regularly scheduled work hours with pay shall be
granted with the prior approval of the department head for:
      Civil Service examinations.
(Ord. 11996. Passed 3-7-00.)
149.16 LEAVE FOR MILITARY DUTY.
   Any regular full-time employee who is a member of the active reserve forces
of any branch of the military service of the United States shall be entitled to
military leave in addition to annual leave, as provided in West Virginia Code
15-1F-1, which provides for field training or active service for a maximum
period of thirty working days in any one calendar year ordered or authorized
under provisions of State law. While on military leave, the employee shall be
entitled to receive his/her normal salary or compensation from the City,
notwithstanding the fact that an employee may receive other compensation from
Federal sources during the period of leave. However, no annual leave or sick
leave may accrue during such service. Any employee shall be required to submit
an order or statement in writing from the appropriate military officer in
support of a request for military leave. Any officer or employee ordered or
called to active duty by the President of the United States shall be entitled
to an additional leave of absence for a maximum period of thirty working days.
Any officer or employee of the City requesting such leave shall notify his/her
immediate supervisor immediately and request such leave.
(Ord. 11997. Passed 3-7-00.)
149.17 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    All personnel hereafter employed by the City whether hourly or
salaried, and whether appointed pursuant to the Police and Fire civil service
provisions of State of West Virginia Law must be bona-fide residents, living
within a forty-five (45) mile geographic distance from the City of Wheeling
Central Offices located at 1500 Chapline St., Wheeling, WV. This residency
requirement is applicable for all such employees except at the time of
appointment or employment when they need not be residents within such
geographic area, but shall establish such residency within six months of
employment.
   This residency requirement does not apply to employees appointed or in the
classified services of such departments that are not employed as members of the
department under the provisions of the Police or Fire Civil Service provisions
or Police and Fire Retirement Systems.
   (b)    All officers and employees of the City hereafter to be employed by
the City are hereby required as a condition of their continued employment to
have their place of abode within such geographic area noted in Section (a)
above and to be bona-fide residents therein, except as otherwise provided in
this section. A "bona-fide resident", for the purpose of this section, means a
person having a permanent domicile within the designated geographic area and
one which has not been adopted with the intention of again taking up or
claiming a previous residence acquired outside of the designated geographic
area. A domiciled resident is a person who maintains a true, fixed and
permanent home and principal establishment, not for mere special or temporary
purposes. A person may have more than one home or place where they reside from
time to time, but they will only have one "domiciled residence." The use of a
post office, part-time homes, apartments or property owned, leased or rented by
persons from another state, county or city, or nonpersonal residence for
mailing purposes shall not be considered a bona-fide residence.
   (c)    All officers, appointees and members of the Police and Fire
Departments employed prior to June 6, 2017 in the City service not residing
within the designated geographic area, as noted in Section (a) above, shall, if
they change their permanent domicile, establish and maintain such permanent
domicile within such designated geographic area at all times thereafter during
their continued service with the City of Wheeling, WV.
   (d)    Failure of any officer, appointee and member of the Police and Fire
Departments of the City to comply with the provisions of this section shall be
cause for that employee's removal or discharge from the City service.
(Ord. 14949. Passed 6-6-17.)
149.18 CLASSIFICATION OF EMPLOYEES.
   The employees of the City are divided into the unclassified and classified
service.
   (a)   The unclassified service shall comprise those positions deemed to be
appointed or otherwise exempt pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA)
and such positions include but are not limited to the following:
      (1)   City Manager, City Clerk and Finance Director.
      (2)   Assistant City Manager, Public Works Director, City Engineer, Fire
Chief, Police Chief, City Solicitor, Assistant City Solicitor, Judge of
Municipal Court, Clerk of Municipal Court, Recreation Director, Public Safety
Dispatch Director, Economic and Community Development Director, Economic and
Community Development Assistant Director, Building Codes Official, Building
Inspector, Housing Codes Official, Marketing/Community Relations Specialist,
WPCD Superintendent, Water Superintendent, Operation Superintendent, Human
Resources Director and Administrative Assistant to the City Manager, Planning
Administrator, Utility Accounting and Revenue Supervisor, Water Treatment Plant
Manager, Solid Waste Supervisor, Vehicle Maintenance Supervisor and Assistant
Finance Director.
      (3)   Such persons filling part-time or temporary budgeted positions.
   (b)   The classified service shall include all other employment positions
now existing or to be created which are deemed to be non-exempt pursuant to the
Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA).
(Ord. 14813. Passed 5-17-16.)
   (c)   Status of persons appointed to unclassified position while serving in
classified position:
      (1)   Any person appointed after May 13, 1992 to one of the positions in
the unclassified service mentioned in subsections (a)(1) or (2) hereof shall
not be retained as a classified member in his/her previous position.
      (2)   Any person appointed prior to May 13, 1992 to one of the positions
in the unclassified service mentioned in subsections (a)(1) or (2) hereof, who
served in the classified service at the time of appointment to the unclassified
position shall, upon termination of tenure in the office in the unclassified
service, be retained as a classified member of the department in which the
member served prior to appointment and in the same capacity in which the member
previously served without loss of seniority rights, Civil Service status or
pension rights, providing that the member was in good standing at the time of
the termination of the unclassified tenure.
(Ord. 12985. Passed 9-21-04.)

ARTICLE 150
Boards and Commissions Generally
150.01   City boards, commissions, authorities and citizens' committees.
150.02   Attendance.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Boards and commissions - see CHTR. Sec.
35
 
150.01 CITY BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, AUTHORITIES AND CITIZENS' COMMITTEES.
   In addition to the departments and offices there will be such City boards,
commissions, authorities and citizens' committees as have been heretofore
established by the Charter, State statute or ordinance of the City and such
boards, commissions, authorities and citizens' committees as shall hereafter be
established by proper Charter amendment, State statute or ordinance of the
City. All such bodies shall have the powers and duties established by the
applicable Charter section, State statute or City ordinance.
   In all cases where a board member, commissioner, authority member or
committee member is to be appointed by Council, or by the Mayor with the
approval, consent, or advice and consent of Council, or by the City Manager
subject to the approval or confirmation of Council, no final vote on any such
appointment shall be taken until at least seven days have elapsed from the time
of nomination, and all nominations shall include a written resume setting forth
the qualifications of the nominee.
   A board member, commissioner, authority member, or committee member so
nominated and appointed shall promptly be given written notice of his or her
appointment, and a copy of such notice of appointment shall be kept on file by
the City Clerk.
   All such boards, commissions, authorities and citizens' committees shall
adopt rules and regulations, or bylaws, for the administration of the affairs
of such board, commission, or citizens' committee. Such rules and regulations
shall provide, at a minimum, the following:
   (a)   That election of officers shall be held annually;
   (b)   That no member shall hold the same office for more than two
consecutive terms;
   (c)   That all meetings shall be open to the public, except as provided by
law;
   (d)   That the time and place of all regularly scheduled meetings and the
time, place and purpose of all special meetings shall be made available, in
advance, to the public and news media, except as provided by law; and
   (e)   That written minutes of all meetings shall be prepared and made
available to the public within a reasonable time after the meeting.
      (Ord. 7001. Passed 4-15-80.)
150.02 ATTENDANCE.
   A member of any board or commission of the City established by these
Codified Ordinances shall attend not less than seventy-five percent (75%) of
the regularly scheduled meetings of that board or commission within a fiscal
year, unless excused by the chair of that board or commission. Any member
violating this requirement shall be deemed to have resigned from that board or
commission.
(Ord. 10172. Passed 1-19-93.)
ARTICLE 151
Planning Commission
151.01   Membership.
151.02   Secretary and employees; legal counsel.
151.03   Powers and duties.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Planning Commissions - see W. Va. Code 8-24-5 et seq.
Comprehensive plan - see W. Va. Code 8-24-16
Subdivision approval - see W. Va. Code 8-24-28 et seq.; P.&Z. Art.
1303 et seq.
Zoning amendment - see W. Va. Code 8-24-45 et seq.; P.&Z. Art.
1351
 
151.01 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Planning Commission shall consist of not less than five nor more than
fifteen residents of the City who are qualified by knowledge and experience in
matters pertaining to the development of the City, and shall include
representatives of business, industry and labor. All members shall be nominated
by the City Manager and confirmed by Council and three-fifths of all members
shall have been residents of the City for at least ten years prior to
nomination. One member of the Commission shall also be a member of Council and
one member shall also be a member of the Administrative Department of the City.
The term of these two members shall be coextensive with the terms of office to
which they have been elected or appointed, unless the City Manager and Council,
at the first regular meeting of each fiscal year, appoint others to serve as
the representatives. The remaining members of the Commission first appointed
shall serve respectively for terms of one year, two years and three years,
divided equally or as nearly equal as possible between these terms. Thereafter,
members shall be appointed for terms of three years each. Vacancies shall be
filled by appointment for the unexpired term only. Members of the Commission
shall serve without compensation, but shall be reimbursed for actual expenses
incurred in the performance of their official duties.
(Ord. 2832. Passed 7-11-61; Ord. 7261. Passed 5-26-81.)
151.02 SECRETARY AND EMPLOYEES; LEGAL COUNSEL.
   The City Manager may appoint such employees as are necessary for the
discharge of the duties and responsibilities of the Commission. All
compensation to employees of the Commission shall be in conformity to and in
compliance with salaries and compensation theretofore fixed by the City. All
employees of the Commission shall be subject to the administrative powers of
the City Manager as prescribed in Section
123.02.
   The Commission, with the approval of the City Manager, may make contracts
for special or temporary services and any profesisonal counsel. The City
Solicitor, upon request, shall render legal assistance and service to the City
Planning Commission.
(Ord. 2984. Passed 4-16-63.)
151.03 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   Except as limited in this article, the Planning Commission shall have all of
the duties and powers as are granted to City Planning Commissions under the
terms of West Virginia Code Article 8-24 as fully and as to the same extent as
if the powers and duties were fully set out in this article.
(Ord. 2984. Passed 4-16-63.)
 
 
 
ARTICLE 153
Municipal Building Commission
153.01      Established; members; term.
153.02      Powers; duties.
153.03     Indebtedness.
 
CROSS REFERENCE
Power to establish - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-33
 
153.01 ESTABLISHED; MEMBERS; TERM.
   There is hereby created and established a municipal building commission
which shall be known as the Wheeling Municipal Building Commission. The
Commission shall be a public corporation and, as such, shall have perpetual
existence. All property, powers and duties and the management and control of
the Commission shall be vested in a Board which shall consist of not less than
three nor more than five members who shall be appointed by Council. All members
of the Board shall be appointed for terms of five years. Prior to making the
initial appointments to the Board, Council shall make such initial appointments
so that approximately one-fifth of the total number of members of the Board
shall be appointed for a term of one year, approximately one-fifth of the total
number of members of the Board shall be appointed for a term of two years,
approximately one-fifth of the total number of members of the Board shall be
appointed for a term of three years, approximately one-fifth of the total
number of members of the Board shall be appointed for a term of four years, and
approximately one-fifth of the total number of members of the Board shall be
appointed for five years. As the term of each such initial appointee expires,
the successor to fill the vacancy created by such expired term shall be
appointed for a term of five years.
   If any member of the Board dies, resigns or for any reason ceases to be a
member of the Board, Council shall appoint another individual to fill the
unexpired portion of the term of such member. No more than two-thirds of the
total number of members of the Board shall be from the same political party,
and no member of the Board shall hold any office, other than the office of
notary public, or employment under the United States of America, the State of
West Virginia, any county or political subdivision thereof, or any political
party. All members of the Board shall be residents of the City. No member of
the Board shall receive any compensation for his services as such, but each
member shall be reimbursed by the Commission for any reasonable and necessary
expenses actually incurred in the discharge of his duties as a member of the
Board.
(Ord. 5894. Passed 1-20-76.)
153.02 POWERS; DUTIES.
   The Municipal Building Commission shall have all the powers and duties that
are granted to a municipal building commission under West Virginia Code Article
8-33 as fully and to the same extent as if the powers and duties were fully set
out in this article.
(Ord. 5894. Passed 1-20-76.)
153.03 INDEBTEDNESS.
   No constitutional or statutory limitation with respect to the nature or
amount of or rate of interest on indebtedness which may be incurred by the City
as a municipality shall apply to the indebtedness of the Municipal Building
Commission. No indebtedness of any nature of the Commission shall constitute an
indebtedness of the City or a charge against any property of the City. No
indebtedness or obligation incurred by the commission shall give any right
against any member of Council. The rights of creditors of the Commission shall
be solely against the Commission as a corporate body and shall be satisfied
only out of property held by it in its corporate capacity.
(Ord. 5894. Passed 1-20-76.)

Wheeling-Ohio County Board of Health. The Health Officer and other employees

ARTICLE 157
Parks and Recreation Commission
157.01      Establishment; membership.
157.02      Vacancies; removal.
157.03     Compensation; chairman; records; quorum.
157.04     Powers and duties of Commission.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Procedure generally - see ADM.
121.02
Recreation Department - see ADM. Art.
139
 
157.01 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP.
   There is hereby created a Parks and Recreation Commission which shall
consist of eleven members. No fewer than six of the eleven Commission members
shall be citizens of the City of Wheeling or Ohio County. The members of the
Commission shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and approval of
Council. At the expiration of the original terms all members shall be appointed
for terms of three years.
(Ord. 15691. Passed 4-14-22.)
 
157.02 VACANCIES; REMOVAL.
   A vacancy in membership shall be filled in the same manner as an original
appointment is made and for the balance of the unexpired term. The Mayor has
the discretion, with the approval of Council, to remove a member appointed by
the City during a term of office and/or not to re-appoint any member to
successive terms.
(Ord. 15691. Passed 4-14-22.)
 
157.03 COMPENSATION; CHAIRMAN; RECORDS; QUORUM.
   Members of the Parks and Recreation Commission shall serve without
compensation. The Commission shall elect a chair person annually from among its
members. It shall keep proper records of all its proceedings, actions and
recommendations. The Commission shall meet as necessary and agreed up by the
membership. A majority of the appointed members of the Commission shall
constitute a quorum.
(Ord. 15691. Passed 4-14-22.)
 
157.04 POWERS AND DUTIES OF COMMISSION.
   The Parks and Recreation Commission shall be an advisory commission and
shall have no administrative or legislative power and authority. The Recreation
Commission shall confer, consult and advise with the Director of Parks and
Recreation and the City Manager on matters concerning the administration and
improvement of the City Recreation Department. It shall serve as an advisory
commission on recreation matters to Council.
(Ord. 15691. Passed 4-14-22.)

42
